Award.AwardTitle: Comparative Network Analysis: Mapping Global Social Interactions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Creating Tools to Map Global Network Structures

The project aims to advance methodological, descriptive, and theoretical knowledge of variations in
human societies on a global scale. Methodologically, the project will develop accessible data collection,
management, and analysis tools for mapping network topology at the national level. In addition, the project
will develop statistically valid and efficient methods for comparing social networks that differ in size
and density.
Descriptively, as the first comparative mapping of global social networks, the project will provide
a more detailed and comprehensive picture of the similarities and differences in patterns of
social interaction across countries with diverse cultures, political systems, mobility patterns, and
levels of economic development.
Theoretically, the project will address fundamental questions about social and structural differences
between countries with different network topologies. The project will draw upon widely used cross-national
measures of individualism and collectivism to test hypothesized structural differences between the US, UK, China
and Korea. The findings will catalyze theoretical and methodological dialog between network
scientists in disciplines that emphasize universals (e.g. statistical mechanics)and variations (e.g.
cross-cultural studies in sociology and anthropology).

Broader Impacts
This project will have broad applications: 1)for the spread of pathogens and public health countermeasures,
2) for policy research on the economic and cultural correlates of the "digital divide",3) for market
research on the diffusion of innovations, 4) for social movement research on "domino effects" like those
observed in the cascading collapse of the former Soviet Union and more recently in the Arab Spring,
and 5) comparative studies of social capital and economic development. Computer scientists will benefit
from comparative data that may be helpful for tailoring the design of online social network
sites. Network scientists will have access to a rich new source of social network data on a global scale. Finally, the
development and dissemination of effective methods to collect, manage, analyze, and compare
multiple networks of hundreds of millions of nodes will constitute a significant contribution to the
social science community, especially when coupled with technical education and training of social
science undergraduate and graduate students to effectively utilize research tools and
distributed/parallel computing frameworks for analyzing very large datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Focus of the project:

Using online social network data extracted from the records of Twitter users worldwide, this maps social interactions on a global scale to test long-standing theoretical predictions about the relationship between the structure of social networks and cross-national differences in economic development, social mobility, political systems, and cultural values.

 

2. Main outcomes:

 

Large-Scale Twitter Data Collection

 

The research team focused considerable effort in building a large-scale Twitter data collecting system that was designed to operate on Amazon Web Services. As a result, we collected extensive Twitter timelines that include up to 3200 original tweets and retweets per user account for a total of 158 million Twitter accounts around the globe.

 

Network Wormholes

Using the Twitter data collected through this project, along with a comprehensive national phone communication network dataset from a previous study, we discovered the presence of what we refer to as "network wormholes," relationally strong communication ties that span extremely long network distances. This discovery, which consistently appears across eight different countries, challenges the old assumption that ties that bridge network communities tend to be weak (i.e. "the strength of weak ties") and opens up new directions for network scientific research. Specifically, these findings contribute to the ongoing debate in the areas of network science and network-based social capital regarding the distinct functional advantages of short vs. long network ties by suggesting that the presence of network wormholes could provide a high-bandwidth information pipeline through which novel information can travel in large quantities, benefiting individuals who successfully maintain these network wormholes. These discoveries can also contribute to a more elaborate understanding of how various social diffusion processes, from rumors, job information, to political attitudes, could swiftly saturate a population via these network wormholes. The results of this work were presented at a number of interdisciplinary academic conferences and an article is currently under review at a general science journal.

 

The Mesh of Civilizations in the Network of Digital Communication

As a complement to investigating the between-country variations in within-country network structures, we also probed the communication network tie densities between countries. Specifically, using Twitter and proprietary Yahoo! email communication datasets, we collaborated with researchers at Yahoo! and Stanford University to test Samuel Huntington's Clash of Civilizations hypothesis, which predicted international governmental alignments along religious and cultural similarity. Instead of tracing governmental relations, this study took a bottom-up approach, mining and aggregating online interactions among millions of individuals around the world to estimate country to country communication densities and the resulting communication clusters. The article was published in the general science journal, PLoS One.

 

Reciprocity in East Asian Gift Exchange

Network science research has identified reciprocity as one of the fundamental and universal organizing principles of social networks. Although the norm of reciprocity is observed in nearly all cultures, cross-cultural psychologists have also identified meaningful variations that have implications for the larger structure of empirical social networks. In one study, we delved into the issue of reciprocity by analyzing time-stamped records of virtual gift exchange from Cyworld, a South Korean social media platform that dominated the social media market in the 2000's before the rise of Facebook. Given the generally strong influence of status hierarchies in Korean society, our purpose was to test how ambiguities in relative status affect reciprocal gift exchange. We find that under status ambiguity, individuals tend to delay reciprocation as a means of tacitly asserting dominance. This work was presented at social sciences conferences and is forthcoming in the journal, Social Networks.

 

Graduate Education and Training

This project provided the opportunity to one doctoral student and three masters students to gain hands-on experience and training in the collection, management, and processing of large-scale social media data and analytical skills for large network datasets.
